Award.AwardTitle: Achievement Scholarships in Engineering, Mathematics, and Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is making scholarships available to academically talented low-income students pursuing degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Qualified students are eligible to receive scholarships for two years of academic study at the college and a transfer scholarship upon transferring to a four-year university in a STEM field.

The project is achieving the following objectives:
1. Providing scholarships to at least 58 academically talented, financially disadvantaged STEM students, including those from underrepresented groups.
2. Providing academic support to scholarship recipients so that at least 80% persist to transfer with a grade point average of 3.0 or higher.
3. Providing counseling support to scholarship recipients so that at least 80% complete transfer requirements, apply, and are accepted as transfer students to a four-year institution.

Intellectual Merit: The project is increasing the academic success of students through financial support, enhancement of student engagement with faculty, and exposure to their chosen field. It is strongly supported by the statewide Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement (MESA) program and by the college through the Divisions of Mathematics and Natural Sciences, Financial Aid, the President, and the Board of Trustees. STEM faculty act as mentors for scholarship recipients to help optimize their educational experience, refine their interests, and assist them with socialization into a disciplinary culture.

Broader Impact: The project is increasing the enrollment of students from traditionally underrepresented groups in the STEM fields at the college. It is also improving their retention and success and increasing the number of students who transfer to four-year universities as STEM majors. Strategies include the promotion of self-efficacy in students, independent learning, and early exposure to research and disciplinary culture. Obtaining a degree in a STEM field prepares students for rewarding high-wage employment in areas of local and national need benefiting both individual students, and local and national economy. Best practices and lessons learned are being documented and shared with other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of Results from NSF Support

 

ECC NSF ASEMS has awarded 129 scholarships to 102 students over the past five years. The awards total $524,000 with most individual awards ranging from $4,000 to $7,000. Latinos represent the largest percentage of the recipients at 62%, followed by 15.5% Asian, 15.5% White, and 7% African American.  To date, 66 NSF scholars (37 Latinos, 10 Asian, 13 White, and 6 African American) have transferred to four-year institutions.  Of the remaining NSF scholars, 34 are on track to transfer, 23 have been accepted and will transfer this fall (16 Latinos, 5 Asian, 1 White, and 1 African American).  Of the 66 transfers, 53 obtained associate degrees (29 Latinos, 9 White, 9 Asian, and 6 African American).  Over the past five years of the grant 89 students have been accepted to four-year schools and 11 remain on transfer track for fall 2016. With the exception of two students who left the program, all the NSF Scholars have been active in the MESA and NSF ASEMS related activities and are currently active and pursuing their STEM degree at El Camino or at their four-year schools.

 

The total number of awards and amounts are given below. The NSF ASEMS project was designed to award $2,000, $4,000 and $7,000 scholarships.  Changes in student’s unmet financial need and/or loss of eligibility for their second semester resulted in occasional variations in scholarship awards.

 

          1        $1,000 award =           $1,000

          35       $2,000 awards =        $70,000

          1        $2,500 award =           $2,500

          3        $3,000 awards =          $9,000

          1        $3,500 award =           $3,500

          59       $4,000 awards =      $236,000

          1        $6,000 award =           $6,000

          28       $7,000 awards =      $196,000

          Total of 129 awards =        $524,000

 

 

 

 

 

Ethnicity Distribution

 

63%    Latino

16%    Asian

16%    Caucasian

7%     African American

 

 

Majors Distribution

 

51%    Engineering
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Summary of Results from NSF Support ECC NSF ASEMS has awarded 129 scholarships to 102 students over the past five years. The awards total $524,000 with most individual awards ranging from $4,000 to $7,000. Latinos represent the largest percentage of the recipients at 62%, followed by 15.5% Asian, 15.5% White, and 7% African American. To date, 66 NSF scholars (37 Latinos, 10 Asian, 13 White, and 6 African American) have transferred to four-year institutions. Of the remaining NSF scholars, 34 are on track to transfer, 23 have been accepted and will transfer this fall (16 Latinos, 5 Asian, 1 White, and 1 African American). Of the 66 transfers, 53 obtained associate degrees (29 Latinos, 9 White, 9 Asian, and 6 African American). Over the past five years of the grant 89 students have been accepted to four-year schools and 11 remain on transfer track for fall 2016. With the exception of two students who left the program, all the NSF Scholars have been active in the MESA and NSF ASEMS related activities and are currently active and pursuing their STEM degree at El Camino or at their four-year schools. The total number of awards and amounts are given below. The NSF ASEMS project was designed to award $2,000, $4,000 and $7,000 scholarships. Changes in studentÃ†s unmet financial need and/or loss of eligibility for their second semester resulted in occasional variations in scholarship awards. 1 $1,000 award = $1,000 35 $2,000 awards = $70,000 1 $2,500 award = $2,500 3 $3,000 awards = $9,000 1 $3,500 award = $3,500 59 $4,000 awards = $236,000 1 $6,000 award = $6,000 28 $7,000 awards = $196,000 Total of 129 awards = $524,000 Ethnicity Distribution 63% Latino 16% Asian 16% Caucasian 7% African American Majors Distribution 51% Engineering 23% Life Sciences 8% Physics 8% Mathematics 8% Computer Sciences 2% Chemistry GPA Distribution 35% 3.0 to 3.3 33% 3.4 to 3.7 24% 3.8 to 4.0 10% 2.6 to 2.9 NSF ASEMS scholars participated in many MESA and STEM related activities including the following: more than 19 students were accepted to conduct summer research at UCLA Transfer Student Summer Research Program (TSSRP), UCLA Wireless Health Institute, CAMPARE Program (Cal-Poly Pomona), NIST Fellowship in Maryland, CSU Long Beach Summer Bridge, NASA internship at the KSC, Center for Dark Energy Biosphere Investigation at USC, Atmospheric Research & Science in Boulder, Colorado, International Research Experience for Undergraduates (I-REU) program in the Center for Microelectronics in Provence, France and at the University of Puerto Rico Tropical Ecology & Evolution at El Verde Field among others. More than10 students presented their research findings at conferences and research symposiums. In addition, 22 students participated in Leadership Retreats, and 90 students participated in field trips to universities and industry sites. Students participated in workshops including writing a personal statement, resume writing, time management, internship/research application, university application, and presentations including speakers from industry and universities.
